metadata.title: How to Build an Image Classification app using Logistic Regression with a Neural Network mindset | by Jalal Mansoori | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How to Build an Image Classification app using Logistic Regression with a Neural Network mindset
metadata.description: In this step-by-step tutorial, you'll learn to build a Cat classifier with an interactive web application using Streamlit. All from SCRATCH.

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: mages and how do computers store images?
Cat image classification app hosted on the Heroku platform.

all_paragraphs: The other day, I was thinking about what project I should work on? for writing my next tutorial blog. So after some time, I think a bunch of neurons in my brain did some computation and fired a signal, that led me towards a thought of 👇
How about making a project using Neural Networks Algorithm?
So now the key question was:

As a project-based learner, I was looking for a hands-on course/tutorial with some basic theoretical knowledge about Neural Networks. So I chose to enroll in the Neural Networks and Deep Learning Course.

Just to let you know that this is the first course of deeplearning.ai Specialization offered through Coursera and is taught by Prof Andrew Ng. The Co-founder of Coursera, and an Adjunct Professor of Computer Science at Stanford University.

Recently I completed that course and wrote an article as well in which I’m sharing comprehensive insights about this course. So if you are interested in learning about Neural Networks then check this out 👇
So I completed the course, learned about solving the image classification problem, Now it’s time to write a beginner-friendly tutorial!
Firstly, we’ll try to understand the problem of image classification by asking questions such as 👇

Secondly, in this main part, we’ll learn about the Logistic Regression algorithm with a Neural Network mindset. At this point, we’ll start coding and implement the basic building blocks of the learning algorithm.
After this step, you will be able to use your own image to classify whether it contains Cat or Not.
Some of the functions that we’ll implement are:
In the end, we’ll merge all the functions into our main model.
We’ll use Python Programming Language throughout this tutorial. And yes all the code include’s comprehensive explanation as well!
Lastly, after finalizing the model we will learn:
This is not the final step but there’s one more interesting stuff 👇
This is my favorite part because we’ll gonna play with our model parameters like learning rate, number of iterations by trying different values of it. And will analyze the performance of our model.
In this part, I will also share some extra steps by which you can play, discover, and analyze the results of your learning algorithm.

Our goal is to solve the image classification problem. To be specific, in input we have an image, and we need to figure out some way by which we can classify whether it’s a Cat image or Non-Cat image.
To achieve our goal, first, let’s understand what is an image?

The image is nothing but a 2D array of numbers and those numbers represent the intensity value of the color. If it’s a grayscale image then there’s only a 1-dimensional channel of a 2D array that contains values representing shades of black and white.
If it’s a color image, like the one you see above, then there are a total of 3-dimensional channels of a 2D array that contain values representing shades of Red, Green, Blue color.
In this tutorial, we’ll be using a color image!
You can learn more about images and how do computers store images? in the tutorial uploaded on Youtube.
You must have heard about applications of artificial intelligence in Robotics, Computer Vision, Medical Diagnosis, Business, and many other domains.
Here, I would like to share 2 examples where image classification plays a vital role.
Our objective is to build a model/algorithm/function that can classify Cat vs Non-Cat images. To be specific this is a binary classification problem.
Given an image, if the model predicted “It’s a Cat image” then the output should be 1 and if the model predicted “It’s not a Cat image” then the output should be 0.
So is there any function that can give us our desired output?
Yes, and that function is known as Logistic/Sigmoid function.
Properties of sigmoid function as you can see in the above figure are:

The Logistic regression algorithm will evaluate the probability of a catbeing in a given image as input. And just to get started we can set a threshold in our algorithm to predict cat image if the output from the sigmoid function is > 0.5 or vice versa.
By the way, choosing a good threshold is one of many stuff to play with machine learning algorithms!
Hey but wait a minute!. Isn’t the title of this tutorial was:
“ How to Build an Image Classification app using Logistic Regression with a Neural Network mindset? ”
Yup, we’ll build our image classification model using Logistic Regression with a Neural Network mindset. Don’t worry about it! (Prof Andrew’s dialogue)
First, let’s talk about Neural Networks!

Neural Network is another learning algorithm but it is very much different from other machine learning algorithms. Inspired by the structure of the brain, an artificial neural network is an attempt to simulate the network of neurons in the human brain. ANN is a layer-based architecture consisting of an input layer, hidden layers, output layer.

In the above neural network, there is a total of 4 hidden layers and 20 hidden units/artificial neurons and each of the units is connected with the next layer of units. So to get started and have a better understanding of the neural network process, we’ll build our cat classifier using logistic regression with a neural network mindset.
Neural Networks are used in applications of Computer Vision, Natural Language Processing, Recommender Systems, …
Maybe this tutorial that you are reading is recommended to you by some neural network working behind the medium articles recommender system!
There are 2 benefits of using this approach:
Now before getting started into coding, let me share with you the overview of the process, and then we’ll tackle each building block of the learning algorithm step by step.
FeaturesIf we need to recognize a cat in any photo, we would be able to quickly identify it and I think that’s because we learned to differentiate between the features of a cat and other animals.

But to let computers recognize a cat in any photo is very difficult to do. Because in the image all we have are a bunch of numbers that represent different shades of Red, Blue, Green color. Those numbers are known as features of the image and that’s the cat classifier input.
So we need to build a system that can recognize the diverse possibilities of how a cat may look in a picture and that’s where the learning algorithm comes 👇

Learning AlgorithmAs the name suggests, the job of a learning algorithm is to learn the features of Cat in an image but we don’t want our model to just predict cat in a single/specific kind of photo instead we want our model to be generalized in such a way that our model considers diverse possibilities of how a cat may look in different pictures.

For our model to be generalized, we need to give many different types of cat and non-cat images as input to the learning algorithm. So that our learning algorithm can learn the features between Cat image vs Non-Cat image!
But what does a learning algorithm learns?

Good question. In my understanding learning algorithm is just doing some computations using mathematical equations and gives parameters values. Our model needs these parameter values to correctly classify the cat with a minimum amount of error.
The algorithm we will use for this process is known as Gradient descent.You will learn more about it in the latter part of this tutorial under the heading of the Optimization algorithm!
The following figure explains the process and mathematical expressions that we will gonna implement!
I know that there is a lot of things happening in the above process. So first let’s understand the process by single training example!
let’s represent a training example by m. So now m=1.
Consider we gave input of Cat image in the algorithm.
Now observe that model prediction is dependant on the value of parameters w and b, Right?

So the above process is repeated with all the other images in the training set and then the optimization algorithm tries to adjust the correct parameter values so that our model predicts with the minimum amount of error!
Note: You can find all the necessary files and code in my Github Repository
First, let’s import all the packages that will be very helpful in implementing the building blocks of our learning algorithm.
These packages are like different ingredients that you need during the process of making some kind of food!
If you are using Jupyter Notebook then import the above packages, if you are facing any issue then make sure that the packages are installed properly.
Now press Shift + Enter Key to Run the cell in Jupyter notebook.
Let’s get more familiar with the dataset!
In the following code, we have loaded our dataset that consists of cat and non-cat images.
Training setOur Cat classifier model will use this training set to learn the difference between Cat vs Non-Cat features.
train_set_x_orig: This is a matrix storing feature values of a cat and non-cat images. These values are between 0–255 representing different shades of Red, Blue, Green color.
train_set_y: This is a vector that is storing the corresponding output value of image features in train_set_x_orig.1 means it’s a Cat image.0 means it’s a Non-Cat image.
After our model is trained on the training set, then we will check our model performance using the test set, this is the data our model hasn’t seen!
So we have 209 training examples and 50 testing examples of Cat vs Non-Cat images. Each color image size is 64 X 64.
Each line of train_set_x_orig and test_set_x_orig is an array representing an image. Feel free to change the index value and re-run to see other images.

For convenience, now we need to reshape images of shape (num_px, num_px, 3) in a numpy-array of shape (num_px*num_px*3, 1). After this, our training (and test) dataset is a numpy-array where each column represents a flattened image.
Now our training and testing set is in the right dimension for computation purposes. Each column in train_set_x_flatten and test_set_x_flatten is representing features of Images.
For example:train_set_x_flatten[:, 209] will output the feature vector storing 12288 values of the last image in the training dataset.
One common step in machine learning is to preprocess/standardize the dataset.
“ Having features on a similar scale can help the gradient descent converge more quickly towards the minima. ”

In simple terms, it means that it will be easier for the optimization algorithm to learn those efficient parameter w and b values when features in the dataset are on a similar scale. There are many different kinds of techniques useful for this purpose.
But for picture datasets, it is simpler and more convenient and works almost as well to just divide every row of the dataset by 255 (the maximum value of a pixel channel).
Before Preprocessing, feature values in the training and testing set are between 0 and 255.
After Preprocessing, now feature values in the training and testing set are between 0.0 and 1.0.
Now it’s time to design a simple algorithm to distinguish cat images from non-cat images.
First, we’ll implement the helper functions like sigmoid, initialize the parameters, … and then we’ll merge those functions into our main cat classifier model.
As you’ve seen in the figure above, first we need to compute 𝑠𝑖𝑔𝑚𝑜𝑖𝑑(z) to make predictions.
Just to get started we are initializing the parameters w and b by zeros. You can also initialize these parameters with random values to check the difference between zeros vs random initialization!
Now that we have our sigmoid and initialization functions ready, the next task is to compute forward and backward propagation steps for learning the parameters.
We’ll implement the following equations in a function named propagate() that computes the cost function and its gradient.
The cost function will give us the value representing the amount of error between our model prediction and the actual value.
Our objective is to minimize the cost function and that’s why we need to compute gradients or change of cost with respect to parameters w and b.
It’s time to implement a function that will give us the efficient parameters for our model to make predictions with a minimum amount of error.
The goal here is to learn 𝑤 and 𝑏 by minimizing the cost function 𝐽. , using a gradient descent algorithm update rule is:
where 𝛼 is the learning rate, and dw, db is the gradients we computed in propagate() function.

Gradient descent gives us two hyperparameters to play with, learning rate and the number of iterations. We’ll be using these 2 hyperparameters to do some further analysis and improve the performance of our model.
The previous optimization function will give us the w and b parameters. Then we can use those parameters to predict whether the image X contains a cat or not.
Finally, we will now see how the overall model is structured by putting together all the building blocks (functions implemented in the previous parts) together, in the right order.
Let’s observe the performance of our cat_classifier model using random values in num_iterations and learning_rate:

So our model was able to correctly classify approx 96% of images in the training dataset and 72% of images in the testing dataset. I hope you know that our model was trained on the training dataset and that’s why training set accuracy is much higher than testing accuracy.
But still, 72% of testing accuracy is not bad. Let’s plot the learning curve graph to get a better understanding of the training process!

You can see the cost decreasing. It shows that the parameters are being learned. Try to increase the number of iterations in the cell above and rerun the cells. You might see that the training set accuracy goes up, but the test set accuracy goes down. This is called overfitting.
Following are the results of our model by changing the num_iterations value:
The above performance results show that when we are increasing the num_iterations value, our model training accuracy is increasing but testing accuracy is slightly decreasing!

Here, we see that the model is overfitting the training data, it means that model will only be able to predict correctly on the data it is being trained on. A technique known as regularization is used to reduce overfitting.

There are many possibilities to improve the model’s performance, So to get started in this tutorial I am going to use the cat classifier model with the training accuracy of approx 100% and testing accuracy of 70% which is not bad for this small dataset we are using!
In past, I also wrote an in-depth tutorial on the analysis of learning rate in the Gradient Descent algorithm 👇
Let’s analyze our cat classifier model further, and examine possible choices for the learning rate 𝛼.
For Gradient Descent to work, you must choose the learning rate wisely. The learning rate 𝛼 determines how rapidly we update the parameters.
That’s why it is crucial to use a well-tuned learning rate.
Let’s compare the learning curve of our model with several choices of learning rates.

We played with just one hyperparameter learning rate, So if you are curious to get a better understanding by trying different things out then, I encourage you to play with the following stuff and observe the changes in the performance of your model:
Congratulations on building your first image classification model. Now you can use your own image and see the output of your model.
let’s check if the algorithm predicts Non-Cat image correctly or not 👇
It’s time to make an interactive web application using streamlit!
But before getting started into streamlit, first, we need to finalize and save our cat classifier model.
Before you can make predictions, you must train a final model.

You may have trained models using k-fold cross-validation or train/test splits of your data. This was done in order to give you an estimate of the skill of the model on out-of-sample data, e.g. new data.
These models have served their purpose and can now be discarded.
You now must train a final model on all of your available data.
By (Jason Brownlee) founder of machine learning mastery
Run the following code to train the final model on the entire dataset (Not on training and testing set ) 👇
Using Joblib we can easily save our model and now we can use it in a streamlit app.
Before getting started into our app coding, you can also play with a Cat image classification app hosted on the Heroku platform.
Streamlit is an open-source framework to create an interactive, beautiful visualization app. All in python!
Streamlit provides many useful features that can be very helpful in making visualizations for data-driven projects.
The Final version of our Cat Image Classification App will look like 👇
You just need to write the below command in your terminal to install Streamlit packages.
You can find the installation procedure for Windows on their official doc page
Now, create a new file, type below lines of code, and save it as a .py extension.
Following is the code of the Cat Image Classification app 👇
Open a terminal and make sure you are in the same working directory in which the file is saved.
Type below command and press enter:
Congratulation on building your first Image classification app using Streamlit!
You can find all the necessary files/folders and source code on my Github Cat-Classifier Repository.

In this tutorial, first, we implemented each function separately: sigmoid(), propagate(), optimize(), … and then build Cat classifier model. Finally at last we build an interactive cat image classification app using a streamlit library.
I hope you enjoyed learning from this tutorial!
If you are facing any issue in this tutorial or have any query then feel free to reach out!
I am a Computer Science graduate and I find myself somewhere at the intersection of Learn, Create, and Share. https://medium.com/@jalalmansoori/membership
